TopicTitle: [1.12.x] BetterTimeWarpContinued - Customizable Time Warp, and Lossless Physics Warp

Articles.Content:
4 hours ago, linuxgurugamer said:

I need a log file.  

You can also try uninstalling it and reinstalling it, make sure the directory gets deleted first.  Possible there is an extra DLL there

I uninstalled and confirmed the directory was deleted. then reinstalled with ckan, same result.  https://drive.google.com/file/d/1IYYuRisis67j0HIjSlD_sk81-2KIDhZw/view?usp=sharing

I downloaded the release on github and spacedock and compared them to the one I get installed via CKAN and they all appear to be identical.  Far right is CKAN.

10 hours ago, eberkain said:

I uninstalled and confirmed the directory was deleted. then reinstalled with ckan, same result.  https://drive.google.com/file/d/1IYYuRisis67j0HIjSlD_sk81-2KIDhZw/view?usp=sharing

I downloaded the release on github and spacedock and compared them to the one I get installed via CKAN and they all appear to be identical.  Far right is CKAN. 

Log file confirms no extraneous DLL is being loaded, that's good.

What's your screen resolution? or, what screen size do you have the game set at?

8 hours ago, linuxgurugamer said:

Log file confirms no extraneous DLL is being loaded, that's good.

What's your screen resolution? or, what screen size do you have the game set at?

I am running at 1920x1080 all of my UI scale options are set to 100%... and that is likely the issue, If I set the time control scale to about 75% then it looks about what you posted in the screenshot.  Not sure what the easiest fix is.  My eyesight isn't great, if anything I need the scale to be bigger.    

There is already a toobar button to open close the menu, do we even need that little arrow button at all?

I am running at 1920x1080 all of my UI scale options are set to 100%... and that is likely the issue, If I set the time control scale to about 75% then it looks about what you posted in the screenshot.  Not sure what the easiest fix is.  My eyesight isn't great, if anything I need the scale to be bigger.

Ah.  If it's a scaling problem, I can take care of that tomorrow

6 hours ago, eberkain said:

I am running at 1920x1080 all of my UI scale options are set to 100%... and that is likely the issue, If I set the time control scale to about 75% then it looks about what you posted in the screenshot.  Not sure what the easiest fix is.  My eyesight isn't great, if anything I need the scale to be bigger.    

There is already a toobar button to open close the menu, do we even need that little arrow button at all? 

 

FYI, there is an option in the settings to hide that dropdown button.  Might be the best thing for you.

It's very odd, because it actually already does adjust for the time scale.

And while I didn't check it with different scales earlier, my scale settings are all 100%.

And, while testing, I just found a stock bug with the alarm clock widget, it doesn't take the time scaling into account LOL.

Testing with version 2.3.13 installed via CKAN, with a  resolution of 1920x1080:

This is with all scaling settings at 100%:

and this is with the time scaling set to 140%:

 

So I'm not really sure what's going on with your install.  

What planet pack are you running?  That's the only thing I haven't tested with yet, it's possible that Kopernicus is doing something with the scaling

Edited March 20, 2022 by TheLoneOne

Has anyone noticed that staging "disappears" on the left side of the screen after using this mod even with unstaged stages?  I was coming back from Eeloo after using five warp and when I got close to Kerbin I went to stage my reentry capsule and that's when I noticed the entire stage tree on the left was gone.  I had right click my decoupler to detach.  My parachute stage was also missing.  I had to manually right click each one and then click deploy.

This was the first time using Better Time Warp.  I'm going to do another quick mission and see if I can duplicate the issue again.  If so, I'll post a log.

This was the first time using Better Time Warp.  I'm going to do another quick mission and see if I can duplicate the issue again.  If so, I'll post a log.

Nothing directly related to this mod, all this mod does is change the warp values.  I suppose if you have it warping too fast that something else can get messed up, but I haven't see it

Hello, 

I have a problem to get BTW running. I installed the mod and all dependencies, but this time warp button doesn't show up in the flight scene nor in the toolbar. 

 This is a screen from my GameData-Folder

This is a screenshot from the inflight scene (normally I have Communications networks enabled, but first I thought it might be a graphics glitch, so the drop down button is covered by the com status):

And here is the relevant Version Information.

Can anyone help?

Edited May 15, 2022 by DeepSpaceCthulhu

I have been unable to get lossless physics warp to work. The other aspects of the mod are working properly: I am able to rail-warp to configurable values, I am able to physics warp both in slow-mo and at faster-than-vanilla values.

Just to make sure I understand correctly: in vanilla, bending/stretching/tumbling during physics warp occurs because the game "rounds" off some of the physics calculations during physics warp. This reduces lag, but can cause failures that wouldn't occur at 1x speed. This mod's lossless physics warp provides the option to instead make the computer perform all calculations as accurately as it would at 1x speed. Potentially meaning that the game will be laggy without a beefy computer, but meaning that there shouldn't be any time-warp-caused rapid unplanned disassembly.

I open the time warp settings, enable lossless physics, set it to 1:1 mode, and then try to timewarp during an ascent. My test rocket (purposefully made to be a little extra bendy, mind you) flexes and tumbles immediately on entering physics warp, just like it would in vanilla. Reverting to launch and trying again without physics warp (SAS, no steering), flies straight as an arrow. Tried multiple times, so it's definitely that the calculations are good but the rocket it "supposed" to flex and explode.

Log here: https://pastebin.com/mg53yxCD

2 hours ago, Qazerowl said:

I have been unable to get lossless physics warp to work. The other aspects of the mod are working properly: I am able to rail-warp to configurable values, I am able to physics warp both in slow-mo and at faster-than-vanilla values.

Just to make sure I understand correctly: in vanilla, bending/stretching/tumbling during physics warp occurs because the game "rounds" off some of the physics calculations during physics warp. This reduces lag, but can cause failures that wouldn't occur at 1x speed. This mod's lossless physics warp provides the option to instead make the computer perform all calculations as accurately as it would at 1x speed. Potentially meaning that the game will be laggy without a beefy computer, but meaning that there shouldn't be any time-warp-caused rapid unplanned disassembly.

I open the time warp settings, enable lossless physics, set it to 1:1 mode, and then try to timewarp during an ascent. My test rocket (purposefully made to be a little extra bendy, mind you) flexes and tumbles immediately on entering physics warp, just like it would in vanilla. Reverting to launch and trying again without physics warp (SAS, no steering), flies straight as an arrow. Tried multiple times, so it's definitely that the calculations are good but the rocket it "supposed" to flex and explode.

Log here: https://pastebin.com/mg53yxCD

Not quite.  All this mod does is change the rate, it doesn't change the calculations at all.  Physics warp is always a problem, time warping using lossless essentially increases the roundoff error.

I strongly suggest that you do NOT use it while doing an ascent

I'm pretty shocked that you're saying lossless mode increases errors. The OP says "Lossless Physics, meaning that you can keep accurate physics simulation even at high physical time warp." What is lost less in lossless mode if not "accuracy"?

6 hours ago, Qazerowl said:

I'm pretty shocked that you're saying lossless mode increases errors. The OP says "Lossless Physics, meaning that you can keep accurate physics simulation even at high physical time warp." What is lost less in lossless mode if not "accuracy"?

I think you will find searching this thread for "lossless", especially the discussion from September 2020, to be useful. tl;dr: "lossless" doesn't mean what you (or I) think it means; it's not clear what it _does_ mean; I still suggest the word should be changed since AFAIK everyone first thinks it means what you and I thought it meant.
